results.title: Spiritual voices from the diaries of war: a narration in five episodes
results.creator_credit: Aleksandr Burov, Alexander Sokurov, Vladimir Fotijev, Eskomfilm, Lenfilm, Studio Bereg and V.V.S. Roskomkino
results.brief_description:
Born in 1951 in the Soviet Union, Sokurov has increasingly gained a reputation as the most important of contemporary Russian film artists. An heir to the transcendent cinema of Andrei Tarkovsky, Sokurov’s body of work forms a rich examination of Russian history and culture, imbued with a spiritual and ethical commitment to the European humanist literary tradition.

‘Spiritual Voices’ was shot with video equipment over an 18-month period in which Sokurov accompanied a young army platoon during harsh and dangerous patrols along the battle lines of the USSR’s war with Afghanistan. Absorbing the gestures and emotions of the homesick young soldiers, Sokurov developed a deep understanding of squadron life. Accordingly, ‘Spiritual Voices’ is free of the usual cinematic bombast concerning war: there is no tightly structured dramatic conflict between good and evil, no diverting spectacles, no individual heroism leading the viewer through a fable of personal and national triumph.

The five parts of ‘Spiritual Voices’ were originally intended to be shown as a serial spanning several sessions for television or cinema. But Sokurov has permitted ACMI to install the work with all five channels playing simultaneously. Viewed in this extraordinarily rich configuration, ‘Spiritual Voices’ vividly captures the mysteriously patterned, non-linear experience of war.

As viewers scan the five screens trying to take in all the information that is assailing them, they piece together an appropriately discontinuous impression of war. Even so, as they sit amidst the platoon’s activities, gestures, and flickering glances, it is clarity rather than frustration or confusion that quickly arises. The work’s complexity sustains and exalts, because the aesthetics of Sokurov’s framing, sound design and editing all imbue the installation with an astounding cohesion. Even though the themes are futility, cruelty and incomprehension, the artwork itself is an inspiring insight into the mess that is war.
results.title_for_label: Spiritual voices from the diaries of war: a narration in five episodes

details.label: Subject categories
display_values: Armed Forces, Military, War & Weapons â†’ War

results.title: The Lost soldier
results.creator_credit: Ken Saunders, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Ken Saunders reflects on the silence reverie of his father, a returned soldier. He never spoke about the war and, when Ken tried to broach the subject, told Ken to let sleeping dogs lie. This left Ken wondering about the demons that his dad confronts alone and the war that took his brother Harry. Spurred by the belief that all warriors need to come home, Ken initiates his own research to find out all he can about Harry and, eventually, return his brother’s spirit home.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ken Saunders, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: The Letters from Java
results.brief_description: Eric Peters only knew his dad through what records were left behind. They were mostly letters that came through the censors at a POW camp in Burma and old photos. He reflects on the sadness of not knowing his dad and the importance of bringing his spirit home to rest.
results.description: Eric Peters only knew his dad through what records were left behind. They were mostly letters that came through the censors at a POW camp in Burma and old photos. He reflects on the sadness of not knowing his dad and the importance of bringing his spirit home to rest.

results.title: The Youngest WAAAF in the service
results.creator_credit: Jean Williamson, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: For Jean Williamson, her time at the Women’s Auxiliary Australian Airforce was new and exciting and, much to her disappointment, short. She joined a few months shy of the end of the war. Still, as she looks back through an album of memories, she reflects fondly on friends made, good times and meeting her husband Noel. She also considers how at that time she wasn’t aware she was an Indigenous Australian. When she found out, she responded by becoming heavily involved in the Indigenous community. Despite her pale complexion, Jean Williamson proudly declares her black heart.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jean Williamson, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

Despite her pale complexion, Jean Williamson proudly declares her black heart.

results.title: A Turning point
results.creator_credit: Noel Williamson, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Noel Williamson joined the RAAF because he wanted adventure and he wanted to serve. While his limited education kept him grounded, he speaks fondly of his time in the RAAF, and the opportunities that he grasped with both hands once the war ended.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Noel Williamson, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: The Sleeping dragon
results.creator_credit: Graham Atkinson, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: The attack on the World Trade Centre in September 2001 resonated with veterans like Graham Atkinson, reminding him of his time in Vietnam during the 1960s and 1970s. Graham tells of how being in the army taught him strength, respect and a sense of dignity for all. Vietnam was a turning point for this Indigenous Australian. He returned highly politicised and railed against violence in his community but left with decades of unresolved memories.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Graham Atkinson, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

He returned highly politicised and railed against violence in his community but left with decades of unresolved memories.

results.title: Compression
results.brief_description: Ricky Morris is the 21st member of his family to see active service for Australia. He is proud to be part of the fighting Gunditjmarra people. His story looks at the invisible pressures modern soldiers constantly face and his realisation that this was shared by his family waiting for him at home.
results.description: Ricky Morris is the 21st member of his family to see active service for Australia. He is proud to be part of the fighting Gunditjmarra people. His story looks at the invisible pressures modern soldiers constantly face and his realisation that this was shared by his family waiting for him at home.

results.title: Back to being black
results.brief_description: John Lovett reflects on the injustices experienced by his father and so many other indigenous war veterans who were not recognised or afforded the same benefits as their white mates when they returned from service.
results.description: John Lovett reflects on the injustices experienced by his father and so many other indigenous war veterans who were not recognised or afforded the same benefits as their white mates when they returned from service.
